CAMERA ANGLES & ORIENTATIONS.description: [SUBJECT](Low-angle shot: camera positioned below eye level, looking up. Makes subject feel powerful, dominant, monumental, larger against the background.)
[SUBJECT](High-angle shot: camera positioned above eye level, looking down. Makes subject feel small, vulnerable, subordinate, or scrutinized.)
[SUBJECT](Eye-level shot: camera at subject’s eyes. Neutral, natural perspective creating equality and straightforward realism.)
[SUBJECT](Extreme low-angle shot: camera very close to ground, looking sharply upward. Exaggerates scale, making subject tower dramatically and feel overwhelming or intimidating.)
[SUBJECT](Extreme high-angle shot: camera far above subject, looking steeply downward. Suggests isolation, insignificance, or a distant god’s‑eye perspective.)
[SUBJECT](Worm’s-eye view: camera almost on the ground, looking up. Strongly emphasizes height, vertical lines, and looming dominance.)
[SUBJECT](Bird’s-eye view: elevated aerial vantage, angled downward. Clearly shows layout and relationships without full top-down flattening.)
[SUBJECT](Mild Dutch angle: camera subtly tilted on roll axis. Adds diagonal tension and unease without extreme distortion.)
[SUBJECT](Dutch tilt: camera noticeably rotated so horizon slants. Conveys disorientation, anxiety, or psychological instability.)
[SUBJECT](Canted angle: sideways tilt off horizontal axis, creating oblique framing. Implies chaos, imbalance, or dynamic unrest.)
[SUBJECT](Overhead shot: camera directly above subject, pointing straight down. Produces flat, graphic view emphasizing shapes and patterns.)
[SUBJECT](Top-down shot: strict vertical view from above. Emphasizes layout, geometry, and spatial design with strongly flattened perspective.)
[SUBJECT](Oblique angle: camera placed diagonally relative to subject, neither straight-on nor pure profile. Adds three-dimensional depth and dynamic perspective.)
[SUBJECT](Side-angle shot: camera perpendicular to subject, pure side view. Highlights silhouette, outline, and lateral movement.)
[SUBJECT](Front-facing angle: camera directly in front of subject. Creates confrontational, intimate, or formal, symmetrical presentation.)
[SUBJECT](Back-angle shot: camera behind subject, showing their back. Adds mystery, anonymity, and alignment with what they face.)
[SUBJECT](Three-quarter angle: camera about 45° off front, showing both front and side. Flattering, dimensional, and natural for portraits.)
[SUBJECT](Profile angle: camera at exact side view, capturing full silhouette. Emphasizes contour, facial structure, and clean outline.)
[SUBJECT](Diagonal angle: subject placed along a strong diagonal axis in frame. Increases energy, motion, and visual flow.)
[SUBJECT](Tilt-up composition: camera angled upward from lower position. Suggests rising importance, revelation, or grandeur.)
[SUBJECT](Tilt-down composition: camera angled downward from higher position. Suggests appraisal, judgment, or descent into detail.)
[SUBJECT](Point-of-view angle: camera placed where a character’s eyes would be. Directly shows what that character sees.)
[SUBJECT](Reverse POV angle: camera shows what is looking back at the POV character. Completes visual exchange between seer and seen.)
[SUBJECT](Back-to-camera angle: subject faces away from camera. Expresses introspection, distance, or viewer sharing their outlook.)
[SUBJECT](Ground-level angle: camera set directly on or near ground, shooting horizontally or slightly up. Emphasizes feet, contact with earth, and foreground depth.)
[SUBJECT](Knee-level angle: camera around knee height. Ideal for walking shots, sneaking, or looming figures while partially obscuring identity.)
[SUBJECT](Hip-level angle: camera near waist height. Useful for weapons, tools, or hands-in-action framing, classic cowboy standoffs, and grounded portraits.)
[SUBJECT](Shoulder-level angle: camera aligned with shoulders, slightly below eyes. Gives subtle heroic emphasis while remaining natural and conversational.)
[SUBJECT](Aerial angle: high vantage from drone, aircraft, or tall structure, angled down. Reveals geography, patterns, and large-scale movement.)
[SUBJECT](God’s-eye angle: nearly vertical, distant overhead view. Suggests omniscient observation, fate, or surveillance over tiny subjects.)

CAMERA SHOTS (FRAMING / DISTANCE).description: [SUBJECT](Extreme wide shot: camera very far from subject, emphasizing vast environment. Subject appears tiny within expansive space and context.)
[SUBJECT](Wide shot: full figure and generous surroundings visible. Balances character with environment and establishes spatial relationships.)
[SUBJECT](Long shot: subject shown head-to-toe with room above and below. Strong sense of placement while keeping environment significant.)
[SUBJECT](Full body shot: entire body from head to feet inside frame. Shows posture, stance, and full-body language clearly.)
[SUBJECT](Medium long shot: frames from roughly knees up. Good mix of body language readability and emerging facial detail.)
[SUBJECT](Medium shot: frames from waist up. Classic dialogue distance balancing expressions with gestures and some background.)
[SUBJECT](Medium close-up: frames from chest or shoulders up. Emphasizes face while preserving a hint of physical context.)
[SUBJECT](Close-up: face or key object fills most of frame. Highlights emotion, reaction, and fine detail over environment.)
[SUBJECT](Extreme close-up: very tight crop on a specific feature—eyes, lips, fingers, object detail. Feels intense, intimate, or abstract.)
[SUBJECT](Macro shot: extreme close range on small subjects. Reveals microscopic textures, patterns, and details invisible at normal scale.)
[SUBJECT](Cowboy shot: frames from mid-thigh up. Historically used to show gun belt; emphasizes readiness, stance, and upper body.)
[SUBJECT](Knee shot: frames from knees up. Keeps most of body while allowing closer connection to expressions and gestures.)
[SUBJECT](Shoulder shot: frames from shoulders up. Intimate portrait distance focusing on head and upper torso.)
[SUBJECT](Bust shot: frames from mid-chest up. Classic portrait framing highlighting face, neck, and upper shoulders.)
[SUBJECT](Headshot: tight framing from top of head to just below chin. Maximizes facial clarity, identity, and emotional nuance.)
[SUBJECT](Tight shot: subject framed very close with minimal surrounding space. Creates intensity, confinement, or concentrated focus.)
[SUBJECT](Establishing shot: usually wide or extreme wide framing used to open a scene. Defines location, scale, and general atmosphere.)
[SUBJECT](Master shot: broad framing that captures entire scene’s key action in one continuous view. Serves as coverage anchor.)
[SUBJECT](Extreme long shot: alternate term for extreme wide shot; subject occupies a tiny portion of frame within expansive landscape or cityscape.)
[SUBJECT](Medium wide shot: between full and medium shot, often framing from mid-thigh or knees up. Keeps environment while prioritizing character.)
[SUBJECT](Close shot: slightly looser than a classic close-up, often from upper shoulders to above head. Strong emphasis on face, still some breathing room.)
[SUBJECT](Insert shot: isolated close view of a specific object or small action—phone screen, letter, hand gesture—inserted to clarify story detail.)
[SUBJECT](Cutaway shot: brief shot away from main subject to related detail or reaction, then back. Provides context and smooths visual continuity.)
[SUBJECT](Detail shot: extreme close framing that abstracts a texture, component, or small area. Focuses viewer on material, pattern, or tiny action.)

COMPOSITION-STYLE SHOT TAGS.description: [SUBJECT](Centered composition: subject placed exactly in frame center. Symmetrical, formal, and stabilizing, emphasizing importance and control.)
[SUBJECT](Rule-of-thirds composition: subject aligned along 3×3 grid lines or intersections. Creates balanced, natural, visually pleasing arrangement.)
[SUBJECT](Symmetrical shot: elements mirrored around central axis. Suggests harmony, order, ritual, or heightened stylization.)
[SUBJECT](Asymmetrical shot: uneven distribution of visual weight. Generates tension, dynamism, and more unpredictable visual interest.)
[SUBJECT](Minimalist shot: very few elements, lots of empty space, simple shapes. Focuses attention strongly on subject through reduction.)
[SUBJECT](Busy composition: frame filled with many elements and details. Conveys chaos, energy, density, or sensory overload.)
[SUBJECT](Negative space shot: subject small relative to large empty areas. Emphasizes isolation, contemplation, or minimal aesthetic.)
[SUBJECT](Leading lines composition: lines in environment guide eye toward subject. Adds direction, depth, and visual flow.)
[SUBJECT](Foreground framing shot: closer elements partially surround subject, creating a natural frame. Adds depth and emphasizes central focus.)
[SUBJECT](Over-the-shoulder shot: camera behind one character’s shoulder, looking toward another. Shows relationship, alignment, and conversational spacing.)
[SUBJECT](Reaction shot: focuses on subject’s response to off-screen event or dialogue. Highlights emotional impact and point of view.)
[SUBJECT](Two-shot: two subjects framed together. Emphasizes relationship, equality or contrast, and shared space.)
[SUBJECT](Three-shot: three subjects in one composition. Suggests group dynamic, alliances, or triangular tension.)
[SUBJECT](Group shot: multiple subjects arranged together in frame. Conveys community, team, crowd, or ensemble.)
[SUBJECT](Deep focus shot: foreground, midground, and background all sharp. Encourages exploration of entire frame and complex staging.)
[SUBJECT](Shallow focus shot: narrow depth of field keeps subject sharp while background blurs. Strongly isolates subject from environment.)
[SUBJECT](Rack focus shot: focus shifts during shot from one plane to another. Redirects viewer attention and reveals changing story priority.)
[SUBJECT](Split diopter shot: two separated planes, near and far, both sharp at once. Creates uncanny, hyper-aware dual subject emphasis.)
[SUBJECT](Silhouette shot: subject dark against brighter background with little internal detail. Highlights outline, pose, and iconic shape.)
[SUBJECT](Reflection shot: main subject seen via mirror, glass, water, or metal. Adds layers, duality, or psychological distance.)
[SUBJECT](Frame-within-frame shot: doors, windows, arches, or objects create internal frame around subject. Directs focus and adds depth.)
[SUBJECT](Deep space composition: strong separation of near and far planes, often with small distant figures. Emphasizes scale and spatial relationships.)
[SUBJECT](Flat composition: camera and subject aligned to minimize depth cues. Emphasizes patterns, color blocks, and graphic design.)
[SUBJECT](Layered composition: multiple overlapping elements at different depths. Creates rich sense of space, context, and complexity.)
[SUBJECT](Looking-room composition: extra space in direction of subject’s gaze or movement. Builds anticipation and comfortable visual breathing room.)

MOVEMENT-RELATED CAMERA SHOTS.description: [SUBJECT](Tracking shot: camera moves alongside, behind, or ahead of subject. Follows action and maintains constant relative distance.)
[SUBJECT](Dolly shot: camera physically moves toward or away from subject on wheels or track. Produces smooth, dimensional approach or retreat.)
[SUBJECT](Crane shot perspective: camera suggested to be on a crane, sweeping vertically or diagonally. Feels grand, elevated, and cinematic.)
[SUBJECT](Boom shot: camera on boom arm moves up or down. Creates rising or lowering perspective for reveals and emphasis.)
[SUBJECT](Zoom shot: focal length changes in place, appearing to move closer or farther. Intensifies focus or distances viewer without shifting camera position.)
[SUBJECT](Push-in shot: camera steadily moves closer to subject. Builds tension, intimacy, or narrative importance.)
[SUBJECT](Pull-back shot: camera moves away from subject. Reveals new context, scale, or isolation as frame widens.)
[SUBJECT](Pan shot: camera rotates horizontally from fixed point. Sweeps across landscape or follows lateral motion.)
[SUBJECT](Tilt shot: camera pivots vertically from fixed point. Scans up or down to reveal height or depth.)
[SUBJECT](Arc shot: camera moves in curved path around subject. Adds dimensional reveal and dynamic circular motion.)
[SUBJECT](360-degree shot: camera circles completely around subject. Provides full spatial view and dramatic rotational energy.)
[SUBJECT](Static shot: locked-off camera with no movement. Emphasizes composition, performance, and stillness.)
[SUBJECT](Crane shot: camera on crane arm soars, dips, or sweeps through space. Suggests scale, spectacle, or emotional lift.)
[SUBJECT](Trucking shot: camera moves sideways, parallel to subject. Tracks walking, driving, or lateral action across environment.)
[SUBJECT](Jib shot: shorter crane-style move with smooth arcs and vertical shifts. Elegant, floating perspective changes around subject.)
[SUBJECT](Pedestal shot: camera moves straight up or down on support without tilting. Adjusts height while keeping angle nearly constant.)
[SUBJECT](Handheld shot: visible camera shake from operator’s hands. Feels raw, documentary-like, urgent, or chaotic.)
[SUBJECT](Steadicam shot: stabilized, floating camera move following subject smoothly. Immersive, graceful motion through complex spaces.)
[SUBJECT](Whip pan shot: very fast pan causing strong motion blur. Creates energetic transitions, time jumps, or sudden reveals.)
[SUBJECT](Snap zoom shot: rapid, punchy zoom in or out. Adds dramatic emphasis, surprise, or stylized impact.)
[SUBJECT](Dolly zoom shot: simultaneous dolly and opposite-direction zoom. Keeps subject size similar while background stretches or compresses, producing vertigo-like effect.)

LENS / PERSPECTIVE TYPE.description: [SUBJECT](Wide-angle lens shot: expanded field of view with mild perspective exaggeration. Emphasizes space, depth, and environment around subject.)
[SUBJECT](Ultra-wide lens shot: extremely broad view with stronger distortion. Dramatic perspective, towering foregrounds, and immersive sense of space.)
[SUBJECT](Fisheye lens shot: spherical distortion creating curved horizons and bulging edges. Surreal, stylized, or comedic wide perspective.)
[SUBJECT](Telephoto lens shot: narrow field of view with compressed depth. Isolates subject and flattens distances, often with creamy background blur.)
[SUBJECT](Portrait-lens shot: medium telephoto with flattering compression and shallow depth of field. Renders faces naturally with soft background bokeh.)
[SUBJECT](Macro-lens shot: extreme close focusing on tiny subjects. Shows fine textures and structures with very shallow depth.)
[SUBJECT](Tilt-shift lens shot: selective focus plane and perspective control. Can create miniature toy-like effect or correct architectural lines.)
[SUBJECT](Anamorphic lens shot: wide aspect ratio, horizontal flares, and oval bokeh. Distinctively cinematic and high-end in feel.)
[SUBJECT](Normal-lens shot: focal length approximating human vision. Natural perspective with minimal distortion; neutral, unobtrusive look.)
[SUBJECT](Super-telephoto lens shot: very long focal length for distant subjects. Highly compressed space and strong background magnification.)
[SUBJECT](Panoramic shot: ultra-wide horizontal field, often stitched. Ideal for sweeping vistas and broad city skylines.)
[SUBJECT](360-spherical shot: full-surround capture as if from VR camera. Environment wraps around viewer for immersive perspective.)
[SUBJECT](Deep focus lens shot: optics and aperture chosen for maximum depth of field. Keeps near and far elements simultaneously sharp.)
[SUBJECT](Shallow depth-of-field shot: lens and aperture set so only a thin plane is sharp. Strong bokeh separates subject from background.)
[SUBJECT](Isometric perspective shot: stylized parallel projection with little or no size change with distance. Resembles isometric game or architectural views.)
[SUBJECT](Orthographic shot: pure parallel projection without foreshortening. Objects retain constant size regardless of depth, giving technical, diagram-like look.)

SPECIAL POV / PERSPECTIVE.description: [SUBJECT](First-person shot: camera stands in for character’s own eyes. Viewer directly experiences what that character sees.)
[SUBJECT](Third-person shot: camera observes subject from outside their body. Objective, external viewpoint on character and action.)
[SUBJECT](Object POV shot: viewpoint as if from an inanimate object—weapon, device, furniture. Unusual, playful, or unsettling perspective.)
[SUBJECT](Drone shot: elevated aerial perspective with smooth gliding motion. Modern bird’s-eye view of landscapes, cities, or following motion.)
[SUBJECT](Surveillance camera angle: high-corner, slightly distorted wide view with possible timestamp aesthetic. Suggests CCTV monitoring, voyeurism, or security footage.)
[SUBJECT](Security cam angle: fixed high-angle viewpoint with grainy, static feel. Evokes documentary, institutional, or found-footage style.)
[SUBJECT](Dashcam angle: perspective from vehicle dashboard, looking forward over hood. Road-centric POV with wide field and horizon.)
[SUBJECT](Vintage film look: subtle warm tones, soft grain, lowered contrast, slightly faded colors, gentle analog character.)
[SUBJECT](Cool cinematic look: clean teal-neutral palette, smooth contrast, soft shadows, modern film color grading without extra objects.)
[SUBJECT](Microscope POV: circular or vignetted view at extreme magnification. Shows microscopic textures and cellular-level detail.)
[SUBJECT](Telescope POV: distant view through circular or masked aperture. Magnifies far-away subjects like stars, moons, or distant buildings.)
[SUBJECT](Bodycam POV: chest- or vest-mounted camera view moving with wearer. Feels intense, law-enforcement or documentary-style, very immersive.)
[SUBJECT](Helmetcam POV: viewpoint from camera on helmet or headgear. Pitches and rolls with head movement, ideal for sports or combat.)
[SUBJECT](Action-cam POV: ultra-wide, slightly distorted view from small rugged camera mounted to gear or body. Raw, kinetic, inside-the-action feel.)
[SUBJECT](Screen POV shot: scene seen as if through phone, monitor, or computer screen, optionally with interface overlays. Suggests digital mediation or remote viewing.)
[SUBJECT](Video-call POV: webcam-like frontal angle at arm’s length. Conveys contemporary communication, intimacy, and slight lens distortion.)
[SUBJECT](Mirror POV shot: camera takes place of mirror surface, subject looking directly "into" viewer. Blurs line between self-reflection and audience gaze.)
[SUBJECT](Split-screen shot: frame divided into two or more simultaneous views. Contrasts locations, times, or characters side by side.)
[SUBJECT](Thermal camera POV: heat-map style rendering with glowing warm areas and cool shadows. Evokes infrared targeting, search, or creature vision.)
[SUBJECT](Night-vision POV: monochrome green or blue tint with noise and bloom. Suggests military, covert, or survival horror surveillance.)
[SUBJECT](Satellite POV: high-orbit view looking almost straight down on terrain and subject. Large-scale, map-like, strategic perspective.)
[SUBJECT](Endoscope POV: narrow, tubular internal viewpoint, as if from tiny camera inside body or machinery. Claustrophobic, clinical, or sci-fi.)
[SUBJECT](HUD POV: first-person view overlaid with heads-up-display graphics—reticles, readouts, icons. Suggests pilot, mech, game, or augmented reality vision.)
